questions.question: Which component of a library is described as the physical structure housing books, staff, and equipment?
Which type of library serves students from Kindergarten to grade 12?
Academic libraries are established to serve which of the following institutions?

options.C: Colleges of education, polytechnics and universities

questions.question: Which library is set up, equipped, and managed by individuals?
What is the primary function of a National Library?

options.B: To serve as the depository of all copyright publications within a country
options.C: To provide clinical information to doctors
options.D: To provide textbooks for primary school students

questions.question: Which component is considered the 'soul' of the library, without which there would be no library?
What is the term for using another student's work with their permission?
Which type of plagiarism involves an author using their own previous works without acknowledgement?
What is the primary purpose of a citation in an intellectual work?

options.B: To direct readers to the source of ideas used

questions.question: What does the Latin term 'et al.' mean in referencing?
In APA style, if a source has no date, what abbreviation is used?
Using someone's work without their permission is known as?
Which library unit is concerned with building up library collections through purchase, gift, or exchange?
What does the acronym OPAC stand for?
Which cataloguing code is most widely used in general libraries for constructing catalogs?
What is the standard size of a traditional catalogue card?
Which department is responsible for affixing ownership stamps and registering resources in the accession register?
In a card catalogue, what are the three specific access points?
Which classification scheme is used by the university library mentioned in the text?
A book is defined as a number of printed pages of not less than how many pages?
If a printed publication has fewer than 49 pages, it is called a?
Which of the following is a type of non-fiction material?
Which reference material contains factual and comprehensive information on all subjects?
Which reference book provides information about the meaning, spelling, and pronunciation of words?
A collection of maps is known as an?
What is a 'Gazetteer'?
Which material contains a brief summary of the content of an article or book?
Which resource is published periodically, ranging from monthly to twice a year, for scholars to share research?
Which component of a journal article provides a brief summary of what the article is about?
In search strategies, which Boolean operator is used to ensure all search words are present in the results?
What is the function of the asterisk (*) symbol in truncation searching?

options.B: To search the root of a word for different endings
options.D: To limit results to full text

questions.question: Which database is described as a comprehensive collection for population and reproductive health literature?
What does DOI stand for in electronic resources?
Which Boolean operator is used to broaden a search by finding records with any of the keywords?
What is the main disadvantage of keyword searching?

options.B: You only find records that contain the exact terms typed

questions.question: Which database focuses on agricultural research and is accessible via www.aginternetwork.org?
Which database is specifically for health-related research initiatives?
In the PQRST method of study, what does the 'P' stand for?
Which study skill involves linking concepts together in a visual, spider-like form?
What is the study skill that coines a new name from the first letters of a phrase?
Which study method involves deliberate memorization for later recall, like telephone numbers?
What is the advantage of using diagrams as a tool for effective study?

options.A: They take less time to draw
options.B: They can be more easily recalled
options.C: They replace the need for textbooks

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an examination strategy?

options.C: Eating a heavy meal before the exam

questions.question: Where are library rules and regulations usually contained?
Which of the following is prohibited in the library?
What is the penalty for keeping library materials beyond the return date?
Which service involves directing a reader to another library for information?
What is Selective Dissemination of Information (SDI)?

options.B: Providing users with specific information to promote research

questions.question: Extension and outreach services are designed to serve which group?

options.B: People who cannot come to the library (e.g., prisoners, sick people)

questions.question: Which unit processes materials by affixing ownership stamps?
What is the purpose of the accession register?

options.C: To keep track of staff salaries
